heading: interest up, markets don't care
subheading: the federal reserve boosted its federal funds rate for overnight loans and its discount rate by a quarter-percentage point. stocks barely react.
author: reuters
text: new york -- u.s. stocks were mixed late tuesday afternoon with blue chips moving in a zig-zag pattern after the federal reserve raised short-term interest rates by one-quarter percentage point. at 3:25 p.m. edt (1925 gmt) the dow jones industrial average was down 33 points, or 0.30 percent, at 11,265. the blue-chip index fell in the first moments after the fed announcement, then staged a short-lived rally before registering a decline of more than 100 points. but it retraced about half of the loss.the standard & poor's 500 index was down 1 point to 1,361 and the tech-heavy nasdaq composite was up 33 points to 2,753.the u.s. treasury's long bond was up 22/32, lowering the yield to 5.93 percent from 5.98 percent late monday.the fed raised the federal funds rate for overnight loans between banks to 5.25 percent from 5.0 percent and increased the discount rate to 4.75 percent from 4.5 percent. the increase in the discount rate came as a surprise to financial markets, but analysts said it reinforced the fed's commitment to keeping the brakes on inflation. the discount rate is the rate charged to banks when they borrow from their district federal reserve banks.the fed also said it was keeping its neutral stance on policy, meaning that it was not leaning one way or the other on the next move.
